ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class is an incredible overview to the 4x5 camera. This class does an incredible job of balancing skills work (literally learning how to use a new tool, printing, toning, etc.) with conceptual work that allows you to leave with a body of work that is grounded in both technical form and creative/personal content.
Camera camera camera
How to use a medium format camera and new techniques in the dark room

4x5 Camera operation, developing, and printing (contact and enlargement).  Basic flash photography tutorial. How to scan and edit negatives in photoshop. How photographic form should match/work in conversation with the content.
In this course, I learned how to use the 4 x 5 camera for the first time and relearn some film developing and printing techniques. I acquired some new Photoshop editing skills too.

I absolutely fell in love with medium and large format photography under Ben's instruction. I only had experience with digital up until this course but I intend to shoot large format almost exclusively moving forward. I also learned a great deal about developing and printing in black and white (darkroom).
Different cameras, mixing light, developing color film -- best photo class at Yale.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: As with most art classes at Yale, this class takes a lot of personal investment. You'll get out of this class what you put in!!
High workload, difficult if you have not taken a dark room class. Teacher is easy to work with and feedback from.

The course could benefit from more structure/commitment to the critique/lecture schedule so that we can cover as much as possible with the time we have. Benjamin is a great lecturer, so it would've been great to have enough time to learn everything he had to offer. Guest visits were a huge strength of this course as well and it would be great to have one or two more.

A more concrete syllabus with explicit due dates would have been helpful. I also think it would have been nice to be able to travel outside of the classroom to see artist portfolios. However, I did learn so much in such a short period of time that the professor succeeded largely in this way.

Ben is an untapped fountain of photographic knowledge and he will walk you through anything thrice over. This class is not for the faint of heart, you should expect to spend a lot of time with the camera. I would suggest you take other photography classes before so that you have experiencing developing/printing.
Ben is an amazing professor. So passionate. No weaknesses except I hope there will be more cameras for everyone to have a camera throughout the semester.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would absolutely recommend this class if you're interested in producing analogue photographic work in a fast paced, critical environment.
Yes! If you are really dedicated to photography, and you are willing/able to make this class a priority.
Yes!! If you are interested in photography this class is a must take!
Yes, you learn a lot about medium format. Dont take for an easy course.
Yes, if you are serious about photography, this course offers technical skills that you should definitely take advantage of as an undergrad.
Yes! But come into it with a clear vision and a good work ethic or you'll kick yourself for not taking advantage of it more.
Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. I would warn them that it is a significant time commitment though.

I would highly recommend this class if you have ever wanted to advance your photographic practice towards an art practice. I absolutely loved spending my Tuesday and Thursday mornings with the gang. Ben creates a wonderful environment to produce new work in.

YES. If you are serious about photography, you have to meet Ben. You have to take every class he offers. He is one of the best lecturers I've seen. It makes sense that he has a theatre background. A true delight. So much knowledge and passion.
